messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Dominating Set, Independent Set, Discrete ùëò-Center, Dispersion, and Related Problems for Planar Points in Convex PositionA preliminary version of this paper will appear in Proceedings of the 42nd International Symposium on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science (STACS 2025). This research was supported in part by NSF under Grant CCF-2300356.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given a set PP of nn points in the plane, its unit-disk graph G‚Äã(P)G(P) is a graph with PP as its vertex set such that two points of PP are connected by an edge if their (Euclidean) distance is at most 11. We consider several classical problems on G‚Äã(P)G(P) in a special setting when points of PP are in convex position. These problems are all NP-hard in the general case. We present efficient algorithms for these problems under the convex position assumption. ‚Ä¢ For the problem of finding the smallest dominating set of G‚Äã(P)G(P), we present an O‚Äã(k‚Äãn‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(kn\log n) time algorithm, where kk is the smallest dominating set size. We also consider the weighted case in which each point of PP has a weight and the goal is to find a dominating set in G‚Äã(P)G(P) with minimum total weight; our algorithm runs in O‚Äã(n3‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(n^{3}\log^{2}n) time. In particular, for a given kk, our algorithm can compute in O‚Äã(k‚Äãn2‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(kn^{2}\log^{2}n) time a minimum weight dominating set of size at most kk (if it exists). ‚Ä¢ For the discrete kk-center problem, which is to find a subset of kk points in PP (called centers) for a given kk, such that the maximum distance between any point in PP and its nearest center is minimized. We present an algorithm that solves the problem in O‚Äã(min‚Å°{n4/3‚Äãlog‚Å°n+k‚Äãn‚Äãlog2‚Å°n,k2‚Äãn‚Äãlog2‚Å°n})O(\min\{n^{4/3}\log n+kn\log^{2}n,k^{2}n\log^{2}n\}) time, which is O‚Äã(n2‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(n^{2}\log^{2}n) in the worst case when k=Œò‚Äã(n)k=\Theta(n). For comparison, the runtime of the current best algorithm for the continuous version of the problem where centers can be anywhere in the plane is O‚Äã(n3‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n^{3}\log n). ‚Ä¢ For the problem of finding a maximum independent set in G‚Äã(P)G(P), we give an algorithm of O‚Äã(n7/2)O(n^{7/2}) time and another randomized algorithm of O‚Äã(n37/11)O(n^{37/11}) expected time, which improve the previous best result of O‚Äã(n6‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n^{6}\log n) time. Our algorithms can be extended to compute a maximum-weight independent set in G‚Äã(P)G(P) with the same time complexities when points of PP have weights. ‚Äì If we are looking for an (unweighted) independent set of size 33, we derive an algorithm of O‚Äã(n‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n\log n) time; the previous best algorithm runs in O‚Äã(n4/3‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(n^{4/3}\log^{2}n) time (which works for the general case where points of PP are not necessarily in convex position). ‚Äì If points of PP have weights and are not necessarily in convex position, we present an algorithm that can find a maximum-weight independent set of size 33 in O‚Äã(n5/3+Œ¥)O(n^{5/3+\delta}) time for an arbitrarily small constant Œ¥>0\delta>0. By slightly modifying the algorithm, a maximum-weight clique of size 33 can also be found within the same time complexity. ‚Ä¢ For the dispersion problem, which is to find a subset of kk points from PP for a given kk, such that the minimum pairwise distance of the points in the subset is maximized. We present an algorithm of O‚Äã(n7/2‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n^{7/2}\log n) time and another randomized algorithm of O‚Äã(n37/11‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n^{37/11}\log n) expected time, which improve the previous best result of O‚Äã(n6)O(n^{6}) time. ‚Äì If k=3k=3, we present an algorithm of O‚Äã(n‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(n\log^{2}n) time and another randomized algorithm of O‚Äã(n‚Äãlog‚Å°n)O(n\log n) expected time; the previous best algorithm runs in O‚Äã(n4/3‚Äãlog2‚Å°n)O(n^{4/3}\log^{2}n) time (which works for the general case where points of PP are not necessarily in convex position).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Semi-algebraic off-line range searching and biclique partitions in the plane",
        "Computing maximally separated sets in the plane",
        "The discrete 2-center problem",
        "A linear-time algorithm for computing the Voronoi diagram of a convex polygon",
        "Max‚Äìmin dispersion on a line",
        "Connectivity of random k-nearest-neighbour graphs",
        "The LCA problem revisited",
        "Computational Geometry ‚Äî Algorithms and Applications",
        "Rectilinear 2-center problems",
        "Rectilinear static and dynamic discrete 2-center problems",
        "Geometric pp-center problems with centers constrained to two lines",
        "Finger search trees. In Handbook of Data Structures and Applications, Dinesh P. Mehta and Sartaj Sahni (eds).",
        "Geometric applications of a randomized optimization technique",
        "More planar two-center algorithms",
        "Finding triangles and other small subgraphs in geometric intersection graphs",
        "On the fine-grained complexity of small-size geometric set cover and discrete k-center for small k",
        "Filtering search: A new approach to query-answering",
        "Cutting hyperplanes for divide-and-conquer",
        "Improved bounds on weak œµ-nets for convex sets",
        "Efficient algorithms for the one-dimensional kk-center problem",
        "Optimal algorithm for the planar two-center problem",
        "Efficient kk-center algorithms for planar points in convex position",
        "Unit disk graphs",
        "Slowing down sorting networks to obtain faster sorting algorithms",
        "Efficient independent set approximation in unit disk graphs",
        "Approximation algorithms for maximum independent set of a unit disk graph",
        "Geometric dominating-set and set-cover via local-search",
        "Optimal point location in a monotone subdivision",
        "Faster construction of planar two-centers",
        "Graph-theoretic solutions to computational geometry problems",
        "Finding a maximum clique in a disk graph",
        "Algorithms for dominating set in disk graphs: Breaking the log‚Å°n barrier",
        "A new representation for linear lists",
        "Fast algorithms for finding nearest common ancestors",
        "Finding tailored partitions",
        "Easy and hard bottleneck location problems",
        "Triangles and girth in disk graphs and transmission graphs",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "Discrete rectilinear 2-center problems",
        "An expander-based approach to geometric optimization",
        "The maximum clique problem in a disk graph made easy",
        "Optimal search in planar subdivisions",
        "An O‚Äã(n2)-time algorithm for computing a max-min 3-dispersion on a point set in convex position",
        "On approximation behavior and implementation of the greedy triangulation for convex planar point sets",
        "Simple heuristics for unit disk graphs",
        "Efficient partition trees",
        "Range searching with efficient hierarchical cuttings",
        "Approximation algorithms for maximum independent set problems and fractional coloring problems on unit disk graphs",
        "Applying parallel computation algorithms in the design of serial algorithms",
        "Linear-time algorithms for linear programming in R3 and related problems",
        "Improved results on geometric hitting set problems",
        "Highly dynamic destination-sequenced distance-vector routing (dsdv) for mobile computers",
        "Ad-hoc on-demand distance vector routing",
        "A rectilinear steiner minimal tree algorithm for convex point sets",
        "Closest-point problems",
        "A near-linear algorithm for the planar 2-center problem",
        "Algorithms for kk-dispersion for points in convex position in the plane",
        "Optimal algorithms for circle partitioning",
        "AVL-trees for localized search",
        "Approximation Algorithms",
        "A study on two geometric location problems",
        "On the planar two-center problem and circular hulls",
        "Unit-disk range searching and applications",
        "Line-constrained kk-median, kk-means, and kk-center problems in the plane",
        "Improved algorithms for distance selection and related problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Dominating Set, Independent Set, Discrete ùëò-Center, Dispersion, and Related Problems for Planar Points in Convex PositionA preliminary version of this paper will appear in Proceedings of the 42nd International Symposium on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science (STACS 2025). This research was supported in part by NSF under Grant CCF-2300356., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
